thread.title: As student fees and living costs rocket here are five ways to go to university for free or cheaply

author: nechronicle
title: As student fees and living costs rocket here are five ways to go to university for free or cheaply
text:
News As student fees and living costs rocket here are five ways to go to university for free or cheaply If you are put off by rising fees and slashed grants then there are other routes into university where students pay a lot less Share Would you go abroad for cheaper education? (Photo: PA) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
British students are graduating from universities with debts of more than £50,000 due to raised tuition fees and scrapped living grants. 
An institute of Fiscal Studies report found students in England have record high levels of debt exacerbated by spiralling interest rates on their loans. 
The average student who borrows £45,000 will end up paying £5,800 in interest, while higher earners may have to fork out £40,000 on top of their loan. 
And with universities allowed to increase fees again, it’s easy to see why many students could be put off. 
But there are ways to study cheaper, or free, by going abroad or looking at alternatives to the traditional route. 
Mirror Money teamed up with Future-mag to find ways students can slash higher education costs. 1. Get an employer to sponsor you 
One method is to find an employer who will pay for you to study. 
Essentially, they’re investing in you and you repay by working for them during study breaks or when you graduate. 
Sometimes this involves a week split between studying and working, or you could be studying full time with a guaranteed job at the end and summer work. That also means you’ll already have a good CV when you graduate , and will be ahead of your course mates who spent uni holidays sleeping until 1pm. 2. Degree apprenticeships 
These are similar to sponsored degrees, but the Government helps fund part of the programme. You will definitely have to work while you study, but you’ll get a salary too. Usually degree apprenticeships, which have been embraced by companies like GlaxoSmithKline, will require you to spend 80% of your time working on the job. You’ll finish with a full degree though. 
To find out more about degree apprenticeships and availability, visit UCAS here . 3. Study abroad The fees are lower in other parts of the EU (Photo: PA) 
Currently there are opportunities to study for free - or very cheaply - in France, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark, Austria, Greece and many more institutions around the world. 
In France students in the EU can apply to the Grandes Écoles for free or a very low fee, usually around £150 a year. This is not a recognised university, but the courses on offer do cover primary subjects such as business, maths and science. 
Austrian universities guarantee EU students the same rights as Austrians, so tuition fees are as low as £300 a term, with some semesters free of charge. 
You may need to speak German though, although Masters courses are sometimes taught in English. 
In Spain, you’d pay between £570 - £1,180 a year. That’s a lot less than £9,000 we pay here. 
Act fast though, Brexit could make things more difficult as Brits will no longer be EU citizens. 4. Crowdfunding 
This won’t work for everybody, but there are examples of students who have successfully set up fundraising pages to get people to chip in for their degree costs. 
But it’s best to have a worthy back story, or offer something in return. 
One successful crowdfunding student, Sarah Atayero from Luton managed to raise over £6,000 from 210 ‘backers’ to help with her MSc at King’s College London. 
The undergraduate put a call out after deciding to specialise in affective disorders and mental health after completing her degree - incredibly, the generosity of her followers helped her reach her target. 5. Further Education (FE) college 
Your local college may offer degrees which are much cheaper than what you’d pay at a university. They won’t always be free, but they will be much cheaper. 
And, your degree will be awarded by a university partnered with the college. 
There are currently 209 FE colleges in England teaching around 153,000 students a year. Like us on Facebook
